content: Indonesian and Malay fried chicken dish ***Ayam goreng*** is an [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine) and [Malay](/wiki/Malay_cuisine) dish consisting of [deep-fried](/wiki/Deep_fried) [chicken](/wiki/Chicken_(food)) in [oil](/wiki/Cooking_oil). *Ayam goreng* literally means "[fried chicken](/wiki/Fried_chicken)" in [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_language), [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language), and also in many [Indonesian regional languages](/wiki/Languages_of_Indonesia) (e.g. [Javanese](/wiki/Javanese_language)). Unlike other countries, Indonesian fried chicken usually uses [turmeric](/wiki/Turmeric) and [garlic](/wiki/Garlic) as its main ingredients rather than flour. In 2024, [TasteAtlas](/wiki/TasteAtlas) ranked *ayam goreng* as one of the best fried chicken dishes and the best traditional chicken dishes in the world. ## Marination and spices Some versions of *ayam goreng* are neither coated in [batter](/wiki/Batter_(cooking)) nor flour, but seasoned richly with various [spices](/wiki/Spices). The spice mixture may vary among regions, but it usually consists of a combination of ground [shallot](/wiki/Shallot), garlic, [Indian bay leaves](/wiki/Indian_bay_leaves), [turmeric](/wiki/Turmeric), [lemongrass](/wiki/Lemongrass), [tamarind](/wiki/Tamarind) juice, [candlenut](/wiki/Candlenut), [galangal](/wiki/Galangal), salt, and sugar. The chicken pieces are soaked and marinated in the spice mixture for some time prior to frying, allowing the chicken to absorb the spices. The marination process might include heating the chicken in ground spices to assist the spice absorption. Most often prior to deep frying, *ayam goreng* is already half-cooked with yellowish colour tinted of turmeric. In Javanese, this process is called *ungkep*. The chicken is then [deep fried](/wiki/Deep_fried) in an ample amount of hot cooking oil, either [palm](/wiki/Palm_oil) or [coconut oil](/wiki/Coconut_oil). The chicken is well-fried until golden yellow. Some variants such as Javanese *ayam goreng kremes* might add the deep fried spiced flour as crispy granules. While in other recipes, these tasty granules are acquired from fried grated galangal or coconut (*[serundeng](/wiki/Serundeng)*). *Ayam goreng* is usually served with [steamed rice](/wiki/Steamed_rice), *[sambal](/wiki/Sambal) terasi* (chili with [shrimp paste](/wiki/Shrimp_paste)) or *sambal kecap* (sliced chilli and shallot in sweet soy sauce) as a dipping sauce or condiment and slices of [cucumber](/wiki/Cucumber) and tomato for garnish. Fried [tempeh](/wiki/Tempeh) and [tofu](/wiki/Tofu) might be added as side dishes. ## Variants There are many recipes of *ayam goreng*, among the popular ones are: - *Ayam goreng lengkuas*: [galangal](/wiki/Galangal) fried chicken. also known as *hayam goreng Bandung*: [Sundanese](/wiki/Sundanese_cuisine) [Bandung](/wiki/Bandung) style *ayam goreng*. - *Ayam goreng Padang*: [Padang](/wiki/Padang_food) style *ayam goreng*, there are several variants of Padang fried chicken. The most popular one is quite similar to galangal fried chicken. - *[Ayam pop](/wiki/Ayam_pop)*: Padang style skinless pale fried chicken, served with distinct [sambal](/wiki/Sambal). - *Ayam goreng balado*: Padang or [Minang](/wiki/Minangkabau_cuisine) style fried chicken. The fried chicken pieces are coated with spicy *[balado](/wiki/Balado_(food))* chilli paste. - *Ayam goreng lado ijo*: a variant of Minang-style *ayam goreng balado* using green chili pepper. - *Ayam goreng Jakarta*: [Jakarta](/wiki/Jakarta) style *ayam goreng*. - *[Ayam goreng Kalasan](/wiki/Ayam_goreng_kalasan)*: [Javanese](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine) fried chicken from Kalasan village, Yogyakarta. - *Ayam goreng kremes*: Javanese fried chicken with *kremes* crispy granules. - *Ayam goreng serundeng*: Javanese fried chicken with *[serundeng](/wiki/Serundeng)* grated coconut. - *[Pecel](/wiki/Pecel) ayam*: East Javanese *ayam goreng* served with *[sambal](/wiki/Sambal)*. - *[Ayam geprek](/wiki/Ayam_geprek)*: Yogyakarta crispy [battered](/wiki/Batter_(cooking)) *ayam goreng* crushed and mixed with hot and spicy *[sambal](/wiki/Sambal)*. - *[Ayam penyet](/wiki/Ayam_penyet)*: *penyet* is [Javanese](/wiki/Javanese_language) word for "squeezed" since the fried chicken is served in earthenware [mortar](/wiki/Mortar_and_pestle) upon *[sambal](/wiki/Sambal)* and squeezed with [pestle](/wiki/Pestle) to mix it with sambal. - *Ayam goreng berempah*: [Malay](/wiki/Malay_cuisine) fried chicken, fried until golden burnt with crunchy flour bits â€“ the signature of the dish. - *Ayam goreng ketumbar*: Central Javanese style fried chicken seasoned with coriander, garlic, and salt. - *Ayam goreng kunyit*: Malay cubed chicken bits fried with turmeric coat. In Indonesia and Malaysia various style of foreign [fried chicken](/wiki/Fried_chicken) is often also called as *ayam goreng*. Common Southern United States fried chicken is often called *ayam goreng tepung* or flour-[battered](/wiki/Batter_(cooking)) or [breaded](/wiki/Bread_crumbs) fried chicken. Common [McDonald's](/wiki/McDonald%27s) fried chicken is marketed as "Ayam Goreng McD" in Malaysia. - Ayam goreng variants - Food portal - Indonesia portal - Malaysia portal - Singapore portal - [Ayam bakar](/wiki/Ayam_bakar) - [Ikan bakar](/wiki/Ikan_bakar) - [List of chicken dishes](/wiki/List_of_chicken_dishes)
